messageBody:
Hi Bernd,

Thank you for suggesting the self shunt pattern. For anyone that is
unfamiliar with the shelf shunt pattern here is a short article I found
that explains it:
http://scom.hud.ac.uk/scomdjd/public/XP/UT/SelfShuntTestingPattern.pdf


What advantage does the self shunt pattern:

public TestSomething extends TestCase implements MyEventListener
{
public void somethingHappened(MyEvent event)
{
//some asserts
}

public void testEvent()
{
MyService service = new MyService();
service.addMyEventListener(this);
service.callMethodThatFiresEvent();

//more asserts
}
}

Have over doing it like this:

public TestSomething extends TestCase
{
public void testEvent()
{
MyService service = new MyService();
service.addMyEventListener(this);
service.callMethodThatGeneratesEvent();
}

public void testEvent()
{
class MockListener implements MyEventListener
{
public void somethingHappened(MyEvent event)
{
//some asserts
}
}

MyService service = new MyService();
MockListener listener = new MockListener();
service.callMethodThatFiresEvent();

//more asserts
}
}

One advantage I see is that the test methods are smaller and would
perhaps be easier to maintain. Is there anything else or is it mainly
personal preference? Any disadvantages?

Thanks,

Kris
